messages: 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:03): why are non-Gregorian dates such a big deal?
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:03): point 1: How many people are actually going to add in <time> elements for all of their dates?
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:04): point 2: How many of those people are cogniscent of the Gregorian/Julian calendar issues?
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:04): point 3: How many of those will actually care enough to do it right?
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:05): if it's that much of an issue, just make it the Hixie calendar: an integer denoting the time in days since Hixie's birthday

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:09): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: If we do that, we'll build up an entire civilisation based on offsets from Hixie's birthday, and then we'll probably find out that actually Hixie was born around four years earlier than that
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:09): and then we won't be sure whether he even existed, or was just a fiction created by the WHATWG cabal
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:10): ok then, how about a better time
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:11): in order to match Windows
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:11): (http://blogs.msdn.com/oldnewthing/archive/2009/03/06/9461176.aspx)
041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:14): how about a floating point number that measures the count of planck intervals from the present time in the current frame of reference
041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:14): floating point just to be sure and present time because it simplifies calculations because the current time is always 0.0
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:15): 041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362: If it's Planck intervals, why not just use integers?
041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:17): future proof
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:17): Are you expecting the laws of physics to change in the future?
041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:17): most certainly
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:18): Hmm, I suppose it's good to make sure HTML5 is prepared for that future and won't be adding to our problems in such an eventuality
041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:19): oh, better make it a complex number, i hear they're all the rage in quantum probability

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:19): 041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362, who's frame of reference, exactly? It would be kind of hard since everyone's frame of reference is slightly different, because it's based on how fast they're moving and slight differences in gravity
041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:19): well, the frame of reference of the author
041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:19): or rather, the document
041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:19): at the present point in time on the present device
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:19): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Relative time offsets from daylight saving is hard enough, we don't want to add relativity too :-(

041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:22): and as all the times you define are relative to the document, it's super easy to say things like <time value="5*60*plank_per_sec">five minutes from now</time> (but saying 5th of march 2007 is a bit more difficult)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:22): Planck intervals from the present time are fine to add into HTML5, but we've got to draw the line somewhere
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:24): let's make it the number of plank intervals since the big bang in a standardised hypothetical reference frame
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:25): chooses to ignore the fact that our current estimate for the age of the earth has a 0.4 billion year margin of error.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:25): s/earth/univers/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:26): Wikipedia says it's more like +/- 0.12 billion years, which isn't nearly so bad
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:26): oh, last I heard, it was +/- 0.2

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:27): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Age_of_the_universe - "Current theory and observations suggest that this is between 13.61 and 13.85 billion years.[1]" - it's got a citation so it must be true
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:28): did you actually follow the citation?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:28): Of course not
041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:28): i.. probably should've written a test generator rather than more tests
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:29): 041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362: But if you wrote a test generator, you'd have to write tests for the test generator to make sure it doesn't have bugs
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:29): the cited PDF has a table that lists the age of the universe as "013.72 ¬± 0.12 Gyr " in the column entitled "WMAP+BAO+SN"
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:31): how about the frame of reference of the Scott-Amundsen Research Base?

041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:31): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: actually, if you take a fault injector that tests your tests (if your tests fail to catch the fault, your tests have a bug) and an evolutionary test generator and let them duke it out
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:31): That only differs from Wikipedia by ten million years, which is neither here nor there
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:32): sure, but if we're measuring in plank intervals, that's a huge margin of error
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:32): the Big Bang also happened on October 23, 4004 BC
041f18d4e2e27cd97f4404c2c67cb362 (00:33): how near c do you have to be travelling for that to be true?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:33): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450, did you just make up the October 23 date, or are there creationists actually claiming that's the specific date?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:33): I thought the Big Bang was the goal of Great A'Tuin in the distant future
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:34): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Ussher
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:36): It's not like they had any better evidence to go by in those days
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (00:36): "Ussher was a gifted polyglot"  :-)
